title: How to Become a Bartender

steps.headline: Wait until you have reached the minimum age to bartend in your location.
steps.description: The age requirements for becoming a bartender vary throughout the world. You only need to be 18 years old to work as a bartender in some places, although the age requirement varies from 18 to 21. Check to see what the age requirement is in your location before you start the application process.

steps.headline: Take any required courses.
steps.description: Some states also require that bartenders take alcohol awareness classes prior to beginning work. Check with your city/state to clarify the specific requirements. Alcohol awareness classes cover DUIs, fake IDs, Blood Alcohol Levels (BAL), serving alcohol to minors, preventing intoxication, and other related issues.

steps.headline: Complete bartending school if needed.
steps.description: Each bartending school is different, but most classes will teach you how to prepare hundreds of different kinds of cocktails, deal with intoxicated patrons, prepare garnishes, pour liquor, and differentiate between different types of beer and wine. However, going through bartending school is not a requirement in all states and countries, so you might be able to skip this entirely. Keep in mind that bartending school is not a substitute for on the job experience. You will still need to pay your dues and work in a supporting role to land a job as a bartender.

steps.headline: Find a job as a barback or cocktail waiter or waitress.
steps.description: Barbacks are bartenders' assistants. Duties include collecting empty glasses, preparing garnish trays, getting ice, wiping down the bar, and restocking supplies. Cocktail waiters and waitresses are responsible for delivering alcoholic beverages to patrons in bars, music venues, and other drinking establishments. Both of these positions will give you hands-on experience working in a bar setting and prepare you for a future bartending job. Work hard so that you will stand out from your coworkers and be considered for promotion to a bartending position when one becomes available. Let your employer know that you are interested in working as a bartender so that he or she can notify you when new positions become available.

steps.headline: Write a simple, straightforward resume and keep it under 1 page.
steps.description:
The hiring manager of the bar or restaurant you apply to is only going to give your resume a quick look to decide if they want to hire you. If the resume is complicated or too long, then they might toss it in the garbage instead. Include only the most important details and try to organize them in a simple format that is no more than 1 page long. Your resume should include the following information in this order:A header with your name and contact information
Special skills and languages you speak
Education
Work experience
References

steps.headline: Submit your application and resume.
steps.description: Bartenders can work in a variety of establishments including restaurants, bars, clubs, hotels, casinos, and music venues, so be on the lookout for bartending . Drop off your resume at several different establishments in your area daily between 3 and 5 pm and check your local listings regularly for job openings. If you already have a job as a barback or cocktail waitress, then set up a meeting with your supervisor to discuss being promoted if there is an open bartending position.

steps.headline: Go to interviews.
steps.description: Be yourself when you go to interviews, but also present yourself as professional and hard-working. Show up 10 minutes early, dress appropriately for the meeting, smile and shake the managers hand when you meet them, and give direct, honest answers to the questions. It is also a good idea to research the bar, think about why you’d like to work there, and come up with a few questions to ask your interviewer.Don’t worry if you are nervous! This is normal.

steps.headline: Know the qualities required of a bartender.
Deal with drunk patrons appropriately.
steps.description: Bartenders are legally required to refuse service to patrons who are visibly intoxicated. Many bartenders do not realize that they can also be held legally responsible for accidents that may occur to a customer from over serving them. If your drunk customer leaves and hurts themselves or someone else, you and the bar can be held responsible and this may include some big fines. You will need to learn to recognize when a patron has had enough, and in some instances, ask him or her to leave the bar. This is another reason why taking an alcohol awareness course is such a good idea for bartenders. Intoxicated patrons can become defensive, rude, and even violent when confronted, so it's important that you have an assertive personality and not be too shy to stand up to these kinds of people.

steps.headline: Update your craft.
steps.description: In addition to learning the "classics," bartenders must also stay up-to-date with new cocktails and be knowledgeable about which kinds of drinks are trending at any given point in time.
